importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Lindsay Sandiford was arrested in 2012 at Bali's airport, marking the start of her imprisonment and subsequent legal proceedings.
Indonesia's highest court upheld Lindsay Sandiford's death sentence in 2013, confirming her original execution penalty.
Shahab Shahabadi was arrested in 2014 and began serving a life sentence, indicating the long-term nature of drug-related prison sentences in Indonesia.
The repatriation agreement was signed on October 21, 2025, leading to the removal of both British nationals from Indonesia and their eventual return to the UK.
Indonesia's last executions occurred in July 2016, signaling a pause in capital punishment, which makes the repatriation of foreign prisoners more significant as it reflects evolving policies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline spans from Sandiford’s arrest in 2012 to the 2025 repatriation, illustrating a 13-year legal struggle and international diplomatic intervention.
The period from 2014 to 2025 reflects the growing international pressure and diplomatic efforts to end capital punishment in drug-related cases involving foreign nationals.

keyTakeAways: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, was spared execution in Indonesia under a bilateral repatriation agreement, highlighting the global concern over capital punishment in drug cases.
Another British man, Shahab Shahabadi, is serving a life sentence for drug trafficking, showing the severity of drug-related convictions in Indonesia despite strict laws.
The agreement between the UK and Indonesia marks a diplomatic solution to the issue of foreign nationals facing death penalties in countries with harsh drug laws.
Indonesia remains a major hub for drug trafficking, with over 530 people on death row—nearly 100 of whom are foreigners—indicating systemic challenges in drug enforcement and human rights.

The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime notes that Indonesia’s drug laws are among the strictest globally, despite being a key smuggling route, creating a paradox between enforcement and human rights standards.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A British grandmother, Lindsay Sandiford, was spared execution in Indonesia under a bilateral repatriation agreement signed between the UK and Indonesia in October 2025. She had been imprisoned since 2012 after being arrested at Bali’s airport for carrying 3.8 kilograms of cocaine, claiming she was coerced into smuggling by a drug gang threatening her children. Her death sentence was upheld by Indonesia’s highest court in 2013. Another British national, Shahab Shahabadi, is serving a life sentence in Jakarta for methamphetamine trafficking. The UK and Indonesia agreed to repatriate both individuals, with the UK's Foreign Secretary Yvette Cooper and Indonesia’s Senior Minister of Law Yusril Ihza Mahendra signing the deal. This repatriation follows a trend under President Prabowo Subianto’s administration of sending foreign prisoners home. Indonesia, despite having some of the world’s strictest drug laws, hosts over 530 death row inmates—nearly 100 of whom are foreigners—and has not executed anyone since 2016. The United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime notes Indonesia’s role as a major drug smuggling hub, raising global concerns about human rights and capital punishment in drug cases.
title: British grandmother spared firing squad in repatriation deal with Indonesia
